com.fizzikgames.fizlib.util.date

Class CustomCalendar

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.fizzikgames.fizlib.util.date.CustomCalendar
  • Deprecated. 
    No longer needed

    public class CustomCalendar
extends java.lang.Object
    The custom calendar allows you to create your own time system for your RPG game using your own years, months, weeks, days, hours, minutes, and seconds. You can create your own amount of each for a given year, and you can name the months anything you want. The custom calendar then provides you with ways of tracking time, increasing time, and retrieving the current time or any time based on seconds.
    Version:
    1.00
    Author:
    Maxim Tiourin

      • addTime

        public void addTime(long t)
        Deprecated. 
        This method adds time progression to the calendar. Call this method whenever you want the logic to have time update. Allows you to increase time by any number of seconds in case you wish to have time dilation.
        Parameters:
        t - increase the current time by the given amount in seconds.

      • getCurrentTime

        public java.lang.String getCurrentTime(java.lang.String exp,
                              boolean convert)
        Deprecated. 
        Returns the current time in a formatted string.
        $seconds = seconds
        $minutes = minutes
        $hours = hours
        $days = days
        $weeks = weeks
        $months = months
        $years = years
        Examples:
        exp = "It has been $months months and $days days since our last accident"
        convert = true
        return = "It has been 3 months and 11 days since our last accident"

        exp = "It has been $months months and $days days since our last accident"
        convert = false
        return = "It has been 3 months and 11 days since our last accident"
        Parameters:
        exp - The string expression to parse
        convert - boolean on whether or not to convert the time values based on what else is displayed
        Example: If convert was true, then 200 seconds would display as 3 minutes 20 seconds if both seconds and minutes were requested in the expression. If hours was requested and convert was true but minutes was not requested and seconds was, then it would keep it as 200 seconds.

      • getCurrentTime

        public long getCurrentTime(int type)
        Deprecated. 
        Returns the current type of time elapsed since 0 seconds.
        Parameters:
        type - Type of time to return (Ex: seconds, minutes, etc)
        Returns:
        time current time elapsed since start, returns -1 if error.
